image.altText: Cars travelling on a busy road, surrounded by grass and trees.

items.synopsis: A man has died and two pedestrians have been seriously injured after being hit by cars in Darwin in two separate incidents.

image.altText: An Asian woman standing behind a coffee machine.

title.children: A perfect storm is brewing at Lillian's cafe: Rising costs and fewer customers coming through the door

image.altText: stadium

title.children: They're the Pacific's 'mini Olympics'. But with a stadium gifted by China and millions invested, not everyone wants them

image.altText: A man and a woman smile as they hold an infant.

items.synopsis: Matthew Cox has been charged with murder after police found the bodies of his wife and baby girl.

title.children: Parents of Queensland man accused of killing his wife and 11-week-old daughter in 'state of shock'

image.altText: Journalist Cheng Lei is seen smiling while seated with the Shanghai waterfront in the background.

items.synopsis: Australian journalist Cheng Lei, who was arrested and jailed in China three years ago, has released her first public statement describing the harsh conditions of her imprisonment and how much she misses Australia.

title.children: Ten hours of sunlight per year: Australian Cheng Lei's first message from Chinese prison

image.altText: Aerial view of jail facility at Holtze, near Darwin.

items.synopsis: A patched member of the Mongols outlaw motorcycle gang has had at least 18 months added to his prison sentence, after unleashing a “particularly vicious” attack on a fellow prisoner.

title.children: Mongols member sentenced for 'particularly vicious' prison attack

image.altText: The ship HMAS Brisbane docked at a fleet base in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Visiting warships from India, Japan and the United States will be welcomed into Sydney Harbour on Friday as the annual "Exercise Malabar" military drills are hosted by Australia for the first time.

title.children: Joint naval drills between US, Australia, India and Japan 'more important than ever'

image.altText: Jacinta Price is on the left speaking in the red Senate chamber. On the right is Anthony Albanese speaking in the green house

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Shadow Minister for Indigenous Australians Jacinta Price have been arguing about the length of the Uluru Statement from the Heart. Who is correct?

title.children: CheckMate: Anthony Albanese says the Uluru Statement is one page, Jacinta Price says it's 26. Who is correct?

image.altText: Grace Corvo looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: Grace makes and delivers homemade lasagne to supplement her main source of income. She's just one of nearly 200,000 young Australians working more than one job to make ends meet.

title.children: 'Young people are hustlers': Gen Z 'willing to do what they need to' to make ends meet

image.altText: Quiz thumbnail

items.synopsis: Have you been paying attention this week? Time to find out.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: Matildas score game with France and MTV video music award nominees make history

image.altText: Lowe gestures with one hand, sitting at a table in suit and tie, a news camera visible behind him.

items.synopsis: Philip Lowe will face the house economics committee hearing as RBA governor for the final time this morning. Meanwhile US inflation continues to cool, increasing the chance the Federal Reserve will leave rates on hold at its next meeting. Follow live.

title.children: RBA boss says it's 'too early to declare victory' against inflation but 'the worst is over'

image.altText: An island-like complex with red buildings and trees surrounded by water is seen from above, a white strip connecting to land

items.synopsis: The city of Bangkok is sinking, with coastal residents rebuilding their homes on stilts and erecting giant walls to protect sacred buildings from being swallowed by the sea.

title.children: 'This not fortune-telling, this is science': Climate change experts sound the alarm on the sinking city of Bangkok

image.altText: Three people sit around a desk in discussion, in a room with official-looking posters on the wall behind them.

items.synopsis: Federal and territory governments have been warned that a shortfall in interpreters is affecting access to justice for Aboriginal people. Yet the problem's only getting worse.

title.children: This lawyer's client could end up in prison — because he doesn't speak English

image.altText: A soccer team wearing yellow and green uniforms stand in two rows for a photo before a match

items.synopsis: A Queensland program believed to be one of the oldest female football academies in the world may well be the secret to the Australian team's success.

title.children: Can the Matildas win the World Cup? We asked someone who won it twice

items.synopsis: It's one of the biggest fashion weeks in Darwin's calendar. And it started with a record-breaking runway event showcasing top Indigenous designers.

image.altText: Sarah Snook, Pedro Pascal and Aubrey Plaza.

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Emmy Awards officially postponed to 2024 in wake of ongoing Hollywood strikes: The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Viral internet star Lil Tay has reportedly reached out to US media, a day after a post on her official Instagram account claimed she and her brother had died. The post has since been deleted, shocking and confusing fans. "I want to make it clear that my brother and I are safe and alive, but I'm completely heartbroken, and struggling to even find the right words to say," she reportedly said. Click the story below to learn what we know about the situation:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Child star Lil Tay is reportedly alive

featuredLink.title: Child Star Lil Tay is reportedly alive, a day after her instagram claimed she had died

children.content: Viral internet star
Lil Tay has reportedly reached out to US media, a day after a post on her
official Instagram account claimed she and her brother had died.
The post has since been deleted, shocking and confusing fans.
"I want to make it clear that my brother and I are safe and alive, but I'm completely heartbroken, and struggling to even find the right words to say," she reportedly said.
Click the story below to learn what we know about the situation:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hawaii Governor Josh Green says 53 people have been killed in the devastating Maui wildfires, and the death toll will likely continue to rise. Search and rescue operations are continuing, and officials expect it will become the state’s deadliest natural disaster since a 1961 tsunami killed 61 people on the Big Island. More than 1,000 structures have been destroyed by fires that are still burning in Lahaina and surrounding areas. "Lahaina, with a few rare exceptions, has been burned down," the governor told The Associated Press.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Death toll in Hawaiian wildfires climbs to 53

props.alt: Many burned out cars sit on a road near the ocean. Burned structure and trees next to the road.

children.content: (AP: Tiffany Kidder Winn)
Hawaii Governor Josh Green says 53 people have been killed in the devastating Maui wildfires, and the death toll will likely continue to rise.
Search and rescue operations are continuing, and officials expect it will become the state’s deadliest natural disaster since a 1961 tsunami killed 61 people on the Big Island.
More than 1,000 structures have been destroyed by fires that are still burning in Lahaina and surrounding areas.
"Lahaina, with a few rare exceptions, has been burned down," the governor told The Associated Press.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Former US President Donald Trump says a trial on charges of him trying to overturn his 2020 election loss to Joe Biden should happen only after the 2024 US elections. "Such a trial ...... should only happen, if at all, AFTER THE ELECTION," Trump wrote in a post on his Truth Social platform. US Special Counsel Jack Smith's office has asked a judge to start the trial on January 2 in part due to the public's interest in a speedy trial. That date would have the trial get underway just two weeks before the first votes are cast in the 2024 Republican presidential primary, a race in which Trump is the frontrunner. Smith's office said interest was "of particular significance here, where the defendant, a former president, is charged with conspiring to overturn the legitimate results of the 2020 presidential election, obstruct the certification of the election results, and discount citizens’ legitimate votes." A spokesperson for Trump says Smith and the Justice Department "are blatantly playing political games", citing Trump's status as a frontrunner in the 2024 election. Prosecutors predict it will take about four to six weeks to put forward the bulk of their case against Trump at trial. Trump last week pleaded not guilty to charges over the alleged election conspiracy.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Prosecutors ask for Donald Trump's election trial to begin on January 2, 2024

props.alt: A man in a blue suit, erd tie, orange face speaking on a podium that reads trump 2024

children.content: (Reuters)
Former US President Donald Trump says a trial on charges of him trying to overturn his 2020 election loss to Joe Biden should happen only after the 2024 US elections.
"Such a trial ...... should only happen, if at all, AFTER THE ELECTION," Trump wrote in a post on his Truth Social platform.
US Special Counsel Jack Smith's office has asked a judge to start the trial on January 2 in part due to the public's interest in a speedy trial.
That date would have the trial get underway just two weeks before the first votes are cast in the 2024 Republican presidential primary, a race in which Trump is the frontrunner.

Smith's office said interest was "of particular significance here, where the defendant, a former president, is charged with conspiring to overturn the legitimate results of the 2020 presidential election, obstruct the certification of the election results, and discount citizens’ legitimate votes."
A spokesperson for Trump says Smith and the Justice Department "are blatantly playing political games", citing Trump's status as a frontrunner in the 2024 election.
Prosecutors predict it will take about four to six weeks to put forward the bulk of their case against Trump at trial.
Trump last week pleaded not guilty to charges over the alleged election conspiracy.

image.altText: A scuba diver examines bleached and dying corals under the water.

items.synopsis: Scientists are concerned that "extremely warm" ocean temperatures on the Great Barrier Reef are a sign of a "potentially catastrophic" coral bleaching event to come.

title.children: Marine heatwave in Great Barrier Reef sparks fear of 'potentially catastrophic' coral bleaching event

image.altText: A Pacific Islander worker picking raspberries.

items.synopsis: Changes to the Pacific Islander labour scheme mean workers must be guaranteed a minimum of 30 hours of work each week, but the horticulture industry says the seasonal nature of the work and weather events make that unworkable.

title.children: Growers warn 'unworkable' Pacific Islander worker changes lack critical flexibility required for horticulture

image.altText: An elderly man with a number of military medals pinned to his jacket.

items.synopsis: World War II veteran Jack Sealy is honoured for his more than 20 years of service to Legacy by cutting the ribbon on the latest leg of a global torch relay celebrating the veterans' charity's 100th anniversary.

title.children: 'Last man standing': 98yo WWII veteran cuts ribbon for final leg of global veterans' charity torch relay

image.altText: A black and white bird on the left, and a white bird with brown wings and blue touches on the right

items.synopsis: It's time to vote again as our quest to find Australia's favourite animal sound reaches a crescendo. Is your favourite among the top 10, and will it win the race for the nation's hearts and ears?

title.children: The nation has chosen its top 10 animal sounds. Vote now to keep your favourite in the race

image.altText: A local resident stands next to a museum building, heavily damaged by a Russian missile strike.

items.synopsis: Ukrainian authorities order the evacuation of nearly 12,000 civilians from 37 towns and villages in the eastern Kharkiv region, where Russian forces are reportedly making a concerted effort to punch through the front line.

title.children: Ukraine orders 12,000 civilians to leave eastern Kharkiv region amid Russian forces' push towards Kupiansk

image.altText: Former President Donald Trump waves after announcing he is running for president for the third time.

items.synopsis: Prosecutors allege two aides schemed with Donald Trump to try to delete Mar-a-Lago surveillance video sought by investigators.

title.children: Donald Trump and aides plead not guilty to concealing classified documents

image.altText: A woman walks in a cat walk in the NIFA's

items.synopsis: Growing up far from the glitz and glamour of the fashion world, Lillardia Briggs-Houston never thought she'd be on a national stage because, while the world is taking notice of Australia's oldest design traditions, big barriers remain.

title.children: Lillardia was 'scoffed at' for wanting to be a fashion designer. Now she's among Australia's best

image.altText: Older man in blue shirt.

items.synopsis: With the country gripped by the mystery surrounding the death of three elderly Victorians from suspected death cap mushroom poisoning, Simon Claringbold knows better than most how dangerous the fungus can be.

title.children: 'I thought it was the end': Death cap mushroom survivor recounts brush with death

image.altText: A burning building next to palm trees blowing in strong wind

items.synopsis: The deaths were reported by Maui County as the devastating wildfire continues to rip through the island.

title.children: 'It's like an apocalypse': At least 36 killed, thousands displaced in Hawaii's Lahaina wildfires

image.altText: A marketing photo of different brightly-coloured watches.

items.synopsis: Law enforcement raid Swatch stores throughout Malaysia's capital as part of the nation's latest crackdown on what it called "LGBTQ elements" of society.

title.children: Wearing a rainbow Swatch watch could now see you jailed for three years in Malaysia

image.altText: Dale Josiah sits on a hospital bed

items.synopsis: Dale Josiah and his family moved eight hours' drive from their community for vital health treatment. He's "overwhelmed" a new facility could see the family return home for good.

title.children: Dialysis keeps Dale alive, but his community makes life worth living. Soon, he could have both

image.altText: A man in a black shirt and cap crouches down next to a racing greyhound with a silk coat at a race track.

items.synopsis: Aerial footage taken at a Gary Johnson's greyhound facility is released by Animal Liberation Tasmania — with the trainer saying the presence of the drone had his animals "cowering like they've been interfered with".

title.children: 'There was nothing wrong': Greyhound trainer fires back at activist group over kennel drone footage

image.altText: Man in white shirt standing behind a podium waves to the camera

items.synopsis: This parliamentary week involved a pitched battle over how many pages are in the Uluru Statement and a bold Coalition stand against cheaper drugs. But no one could stay grumpy when Kevin Rudd's official portrait was unveiled, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: It was a tricky week in parliament for Anthony Albanese. Then Kevin Rudd made a comeback

image.altText: Exterior gate at Risdon prison, Tasmania.

items.synopsis: The number of meetings potentially compromised by the covert police surveillance of a room at Tasmania's Risdon Prison could number in the hundreds, it has been revealed — with the matter described as a "massive breach of privacy" which demands a "comprehensive review".

title.children: Police live-streamed potentially hundreds of legally privileged lawyer-prisoner conversations in bugged room

image.altText: a woman standing in a doorway of an office and shop

items.synopsis: Chinese group tours are set to return to Australia but local tourism operators warn they may not have capacity to accommodate them.

title.children: Calls for government assistance as Chinese tour groups allowed to return to Australia

image.altText: Peter Dutton sits in the House of Representatives

items.synopsis: Crazy brave, or just crazy? If, as seems likely, the opposition embraces nuclear power in its 2025 election policy, it will be taking a huge political gamble, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Will Australians embrace nuclear? The Coalition might take the gamble
